structured_notes.meeting_objective: To brainstorm and define the core features, target audience, and business model for a new fitness application.
key_discussion_points: Defining the target audience as fitness beginners rather than hardcore athletes.
Identifying core features: workout tracking, pre-made plans, and exercise demonstrations.
Discussing nutrition tracking methods, settling on photo logging with AI analysis.
Exploring gamification elements like badges and achievements to increase engagement.
Debating the scope of social features for the initial version.
Outlining a freemium monetization model with a premium subscription.
Establishing the technical stack, including React Native for mobile and AWS for hosting.
pain_points: Difficulty competing with large companies like Apple.
High infrastructure costs for hosting video demonstrations.
Potential inaccuracies of AI food recognition.
Risks associated with social features, such as moderation and privacy.
Users feeling overwhelmed by existing, complex fitness apps.
requirements: The app must be beginner-friendly and simple to use.
Include workout logging functionality (exercises, sets, reps).
Provide pre-made workout plans for beginners.
Feature exercise demonstrations (starting with images/GIFs or links).
Implement meal photo tracking with AI analysis.
Offer progress visualization with beautiful, non-boring charts.
Include basic social features for private progress sharing.
Integrate with Apple Health and Google Fit.
decisions_made: Target audience will be fitness beginners (ages 25-45) who find other apps intimidating.
Core features for V1 will include workout tracking, pre-made plans, exercise demos, meal photo tracking with AI, progress visualization, and basic private social sharing.
Nutrition tracking will use photo logging with AI analysis instead of manual calorie counting.
Monetization will be a freemium model at $9.99/month or $79.99/year for premium features like advanced plans and analytics.
The tech stack will be React Native for mobile, Node.js for the backend, and hosted on AWS.
The platform will be mobile-first, with no web version planned for the initial launch.
The project timeline is estimated at 6-8 months.
V1 integrations will focus on Apple Health and Google Fit, postponing Strava.
action_items: Sarah will create a formal Product Requirements Document (PRD) based on the discussion for review in the next week's meeting.
technical_constraints: Video hosting is too expensive for the MVP; alternatives like images, GIFs, or linking to external videos will be used.
AI for food recognition will be implemented via existing third-party APIs (e.g., Clarifai, Google Cloud Vision) rather than building a custom model.
Development will use React Native to support both iOS and Android from a single codebase.
